# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: â€œyyyymmâ€.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is a Julia function that does the job. We use the built-in DateTime type to extract year and month from DateTimes, then concatenate them together as an integer in format "yyyymm".

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> string(year(x)) * string(month(x)), df.dt) |> x -> parse.(Int, x)
    return df
end
```

You can use this function on a DataFrame like so:

```julia
df = DataFrame(dt=DateTime[now() - i*Month(1) for i in 1:3])
add_yearmonth(df)
```

This will add a new column `ym` to the DataFrame, with each value being an integer representing the year and month of the corresponding DateTime.

If you want to make sure that the result is always a two-digit number (e.g., "2021" instead of just "21"), you can modify the function like so:

```julia
function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> string(year(x), pad=true, width=4) * string(month(x), pad=true, width=2), df.dt) |> x -> parse.(Int, x)
    return df
end
```
